title-group.article-title: A Gender Analysis of NBC’s Coverage of the 2008 Summer Olympics

bio.title: Bios
bio.p: Kelly K. Davis is assistant professor of communication at Appalachian State University. His research interests include ethnic, gender and racial representation on television. He has produced non-fiction programming for national public television audiences.

C.A. Tuggle is professor and Director of the Journalism Program at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. His research interests include newsroom practices and coverage of women's athletics. He spent 16 years in local television news.

article-meta.aff: 1School of Journalism and Mass Communication, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Chapel Hill, NC, USA

author-notes.corresp: Kelly Davis, School of Journalism and Mass Communication, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, Carroll Hall 117, CB 3365, Chapel Hill, NC 27599, USA Email: kkdavis@live.unc.edu

abstract.p: This study examines National Broadcasting Company (NBC)’s U.S. broadcast coverage of the 2008 Summer Olympic Games for gender equality and compares that coverage to previous years. Olympics coverage is particularly important to female athletes because many receive little media attention beyond Olympic competition. The study found that, while female participation in the Olympics has increased, NBC’s coverage of women’s events has not, and 97% of airtime devoted to women’s events was confined to six “socially acceptable” sports.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In this study, we examine the amount and scope of National Broadcasting Company (NBC)’s coverage (as broadcast to the United States) of men and women competing in the 2008 Summer Olympic Games and how that coverage compares to previous years. Who and what are covered at the Olympic Games is particularly important to women in sports, because many of those athletes and the sports they participate in receive little coverage beyond Olympic competition. How they are framed on the world’s largest and most important sports stage warrants close scrutiny.

sec.title: Literature Review
sec.p: The Olympic Charter (International Olympics Committee, 2007) declares sport to be a human right, open to all people “in the Olympic spirit, which requires mutual understanding with a spirit of friendship, solidarity and fair play.” Its guiding principles include a rejection of any form of that based on discrimination, including race, religion, and gender. Because of the spirit of international cooperation of the events, and because of their extraordinary worldwide popularity, the Olympic Games represent multicultural acceptance and egalitarianism unmatched by all but the most far-reaching international organizations.

News coverage of sports, however, has never been as egalitarian as the Olympic ideal, particularly in regard to gender. In a series of content analyses of news and highlight shows between 1989 and 2004, Duncan, Messner, and Williams (2005) found that the small percentage of sports coverage devoted to women—less than 10%—has not significantly changed. Female Olympians fare much better, but still receive less attention than men (Billings, 2008; Bissell & Holt 2005; Tuggle, 1997; Tuggle, Huffman, & Rosengard, 2002; Tuggle and Owen, 1999). This paucity of reporting has reinforced the stereotypical dominance of male athletes, making female athletes at best marginal and at worst, nearly invisible (Hargreaves, 1993, 1994).

Lack of parity of attention takes a toll on the audience as well as the participants. Several studies in the United Kingdom have found that girls find it challenging to manage preconceptions of femininity and sexuality while participating in sports (Cockburn & Clarke, 2003; Harris, 2007). This is despite the fact that, during the past 35 years, the number of American girls playing varsity sports has risen from one of the every 27 to one of the three (Benjamin, 2007).

The overall cultural significance of sport cannot be underestimated in this regard. Rowe (1999, p. 23) explains it this way: “If culture is the ‘stuff’ of everyday life—the frame through which we experience, interpret, mould and represent everything that surrounds us—then sport occupies. . .an uncommonly prominent position within it.”

Television coverage is a frame, a window on the world, through which we learn of ourselves and others (Tuchman, 1978a). Frames are important because they help build “the pictures. . . in our heads”—the stereotypes on which we base our thinking (Lippmann, 1922, p. 59). Edelman (1993, p. 232) describes the social world as “a kaleidoscope of potential realities, any of which can be readily evoked by altering the ways in which observations are framed and categorized.”

The sports industry and sports media have traditionally been male defined and controlled (McDaniel & Sullivan, 1998). Framing theory suggests that gender stereotypes persist in media coverage because ways of representing gender have become standardized in news practice (Gamson & Modigliani, 1989; Pan & Kosicki, 1993). According to Entman (1993, p. 52), news workers incorporate framing when they “select some aspects of a perceived reality and make them more [or less] salient in communicating a text.” Framing is thus achieved through the processes of selecting events for coverage and then producing the coverage (Entman, 1993; Gitlin, 1980; Tuchman, 1978b).

Women were not allowed to compete in the first modern Olympics in 1896 because it was thought to be “inappropriate” for them to do so (May-Mons, 2000). At the 1900 Olympics in Paris, France, women competed in only tennis and golf. The percentage of female competitors has risen steadily since their initial inclusion in the 1900 games, when they comprised only 1.6% of competitors (International Olympics Committee, 2009). Now women compete in all Olympic sports except baseball and boxing. Four thousand six hundred and nine women competed in the 2008 Olympics in Beijing, China, comprising 42.3% of the 10,904 competitors (International Olympics Committee, 2009).

The 1960 Games marked the first-time women’s events were televised into U.S. homes (Creedon, 1994), and both the number of females competing and the proportion of broadcast coverage devoted to them have increased with each successive Olympics until the 2000 Games (Leder, 1996).

Numerous researchers (Boutilier & SanGiovanni, 1983; Bryant, 1980; Duncan and Messner, 1994; Hallmark & Armstrong, 1999; Hilliard, 1984; Himmelberg, 1992; Huffman, Tuggle, & Rosengard, 2004; Lattimore, 1996; Messner, 1992; Tuggle, 1997; Tuggle et al., 2002; Tuggle and Owen, 1999) have found that coverage of female athletes pales in comparison to coverage of males in sports at all competition levels. This difference manifests itself in several ways: (1) total column inches and running times, (2) persons quoted, (3) placement of articles and stories, (4) presence and size/length, (5) placement of an accompanying photograph or videotaped highlight, (6) the range of sports depicted in photos and tapes, and (7) the size and content of newspaper headlines and magazine article titles. In a study examining gender representation of female athletes on three leading sports websites (CBS SportsLine, CNNSI, and ESPN), Kachgal (2001) found that female athletes received less coverage than male athletes. Huffman, Tuggle, and Rosengard (2004) found that campus media, covering both professional and amateur sports, also devoted significantly more space and time to male athletes than female athletes.

Further, Kane (1989) found that women in more “feminine” or “socially acceptable” sports such as tennis and golf received significantly more coverage than women who participated in “socially unacceptable” sports. Eleanor Metheny observed that social mores influenced the acceptability of a sport type for women because femininity requires graceful and aesthetically pleasing body motion (Metheny, 1965). Her taxonomy included swimming, gymnastics, and tennis as socially acceptable sports, while softball, basketball, and track were unacceptable. This was confirmed by survey research (Spreitzer, Snyder & Kivlin, 1978) and has remained stable over time (Kane, 1996). Kane and Parks (1990) found that women participating in “acceptable” sport types received more coverage in Sports Illustrated than did women engaged in “unacceptable” sports. Lumpkin and Williams (1991) found that this was true regardless of race, and Leath and Lumpkin (1992) found it to be true even of a magazine devoted to women in sport. In the 1992 summer Olympics, women in feminine, individual sports such as tennis and gymnastics were given more airtime than those playing team sports like basketball.

Messner (1992) concluded that sports news means men’s sports news and that sport is a key component to our current gender order. “A key to whether or not increasing female athleticism will amount to a real challenge to sport’s role in a system of masculine domination is whether and how the media cover girls’ and women’s sport” (Messner, 1992, p. 164).

Historically, women’s team sports have been slower to gain acceptance at the Olympics than have individual women’s sports (Leder, 1996). In their content analysis of NBC’s coverage of the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta, Tuggle and Owen (1999) found that men’s team competitions received substantially more coverage than did women’s team events, and women in sports that involved power or hard physical contact between athletes received almost no attention. In their study of NBC’s coverage of the Summer Olympics in Sydney, Tuggle, Huffman, and Rosengard (2002) found that women received proportionately less coverage in 2000 than they did in 1996 on the U.S. network. In Athens, NBC’s coverage of women’s events returned to the 1996 levels, even though women comprised a smaller portion of the total number of athletes competing (Tuggle, Huffman, & Rosengard, 2007). In both the Games, however, coverage focused on individual events, with women competing in team sports receiving relatively little coverage. As was the case in 1996, women who competed in 2000 in sports involving power or hard physical contact received almost no attention. The same was true in 2004.

The degree to which the media cover female athletes helps mold society’s view of female athletes and its perceptions of women in general. Sports media reflect, shape, and might even help create attitudes and values about what type of sports participation is appropriate and acceptable for females. Decisions about which sports to cover and how extensively to cover them can reinforce preconceived concepts among audience members about which sports and which athletes really matter and create a self-perpetuation stereotype of women and sports.

Sportswriters and sportscasters must be selective in what they cover because of limitations of resources, space and/or time, and often base their coverage on the perceived level of reader or viewer interest (Belliotti, 1983). NBC appears to have been successful in this, as it consistently led in national broadcast ratings, and in sum achieved the status of the highest viewership of any televised event of all time (TVWeek, 2008).

Despite the ratings success, NBC’s coverage did not come without some criticism. Some accuse NBC Sports of devoting a disproportionate amount of coverage of women’s events to those that involved leotards and swimsuits (Billings, 2008; Mediapost, 2004). In the 2008 Summer Games, men’s volleyball and beach volleyball were equally covered (approximately 2 hr of total time each), while women’s volleyball received no coverage, and women’s beach volleyball was 1.75 times that of men’s. All four teams earned medals (Sports Reference, 2008), and yet the women’s coverage was limited to the bikini-clad athletes. Some would argue that this was not an accident.

sec.title: Research Hypotheses
sec.p: Based on previous research, we make the following predictions concerning NBC’s coverage of male and female athletes competing in the 2008 Summer Olympics.

Men’s team sports typically gather more attention than women’s team sports. Additionally, men’s team sports outnumbered women’s team sports in Beijing 34 to 32, and so it is expected that coverage of men’s team sports will outweigh coverage of women’s team sports.

list-item.p: Hypothesis 1. Men’s team sports will receive slightly more coverage than women’s team sports.

sec.p: Previous studies have found that television coverage of women’s sports in general tends toward events such as tennis, golf, gymnastics, and swimming, what some have called “socially acceptable” sports for women. Tuggle et al. (2002, 2007) found that the most-covered events for women in both the Sydney (2000) and Athens (2004) Summer Games were gymnastics, diving, swimming, and track, gymnastics being the clear leader. Beach volleyball, a new event in 2004, joined the list. All of these sports are defined by the authors to be “socially acceptable” forms of female athleticism. NBC’s coverage of the 2008 Summer Olympics is expected to follow this pattern.

list-item.p: Hypothesis 2. “Socially acceptable” sports will comprise the bulk of women’s individual and team coverage.

sec.p: Kane (1989) and Tuggle and Owen (1999) found that women involved in sports that require physical bulk, power, and/or hard physical contact between athletes receive almost no coverage compared to women competing in what Kane called “socially acceptable” sports, such as gymnastics and swimming.

list-item.p: Hypothesis 3. Coverage of power or hard contact sports will focus on males, with females involved in such events receiving relatively little attention.

sec.p: Duncan and Messner (1994) and Tuggle (1997) found that males associated with the Olympic games are quoted more frequently than their female counterparts in sports highlights programs, in addition to being the subjects of an overwhelming majority of the coverage. Although the amount of coverage of women competing in the 2008 Olympics is expected to be more balanced than that found in highlights programs in the past, the proportion of females as on-camera sources is expected to mirror what was found in earlier studies.

list-item.p: Hypothesis 4. Quotes will be more likely to come from male competitors, coaches, officials, and observers than from females in the same roles.

sec.title: Method
sec.p: NBC in recent years has expanded coverage of Olympic events into other day parts and onto its website—in the 2008 Olympics, 61% of its video coverage was online (Stelter, 2010). Last year, NBC announced its intention to stream and broadcast the 2012 Olympics live, a departure from its previous policy of holding broadcasts of sports the network expected to draw broad interest until prime time (Cromwell, 2011). However, this has not diminished the importance of the prime-time broadcast, when networks can reach the largest audiences and make the most revenue from advertisers. From 1988 to 2004, average prime-time Olympic broadcast ratings were at least twice as high as those in other day parts (Nielsen, 2008a). Indeed, NBC intends to rebroadcast events of high interest in prime time to a larger audience (Cromwell, 2011).

NBC’s Internet coverage attracted approximately 33.8 million unique visitors during the 2-week event (The Nielsen Company, 2008b), not quite equaling the 34.8 million viewers of the opening ceremony on Friday, August 8. NBC’s average prime-time viewership during the 2-week period was approximately 27.7 million people (The Nielsen Company, 2008, August 27). In 2009, advertisers spent 57% of their money on television, 50% of which was spent on prime-time broadcast advertising. By contrast, only 7% of ad revenue went to the Internet (The Nielsen Company, 2010). In fact, NBC dialed back its online streaming coverage of the 2010 Vancouver Games to 48%, in part to encourage prime-time viewership (Stelter, 2010).

Aside from its coverage on its main channel, NBC Universal also broadcast events and highlights of the Beijing Olympics on its cable networks, USA, Telemundo, MSNBC, CNBC, and Oxygen. While the latter three received a substantial ratings bump from their Olympics coverage, the combined daily ratings of these five cable channels during their Olympics coverage was approximately 12% the size of NBC’s daily ratings (Magna International, Inc., 2008).

For these reasons, the authors chose to concentrate on the prime-time broadcasts of the NBC main channel. The sample consisted of digital video recordings of NBC’s prime-time Olympics coverage for the dates August 8–24, 2008; a total of 16 days, 15 of which involved competition. Opening and closing ceremonies were not included in the analysis. Also removed from analysis were segments that did not include direct participation by athletes, such as stories detailing the history of China, or other human-interest features.

Once all data were collected, the content was coded. The unit of analysis was the broadcast segment. 1 This study replicated the coding schemes of previous studies of the Olympic Games (Tuggle, 1997; Tuggle & Owen, 1999; Tuggle et al., 2002). Coding indicated the sport, the length of the segment, the type of presentation (event, interview, awards ceremony, etc.), the sex of the participants, the role of quoted sources (athlete, coach, sports official, etc.) whether the segment was presented live (or as live) or edited into condensed form, whether the competition involved physical power or hard body contact as a primary component, and whether individual or team medals were at stake. In addition, coding indicated the job description of all speakers (anchor, reporter, etc.) and the speaker’s sex. Coding was completed by the authors. Because all data were categorical in nature (i.e., either a segment fell into a category or did not), calculating intercoder reliability was not necessary. The data were then compiled using SPSS 16.0 for Windows. Because the study captures the entire population under study (all of NBC’s prime-time Olympics coverage), there is no need for inferential statistics, as measured differences in percentages were actual differences, not projected differences based on a sample of the coverage. Nonparametric tests are used.

sec.title: Findings
sec.p: In 2008, women competed in 42% (127) of the 302 Olympic events. American women made up 48% (286) of the U.S. team, and claimed 48% (53) of the nation’s 110 medals (Sports Reference, 2008). Teams consisting of men and women competing together netted 4 medals, and men claimed 53 (48%) (Sports Reference, 2008). Hence, women’s medal success was proportional to the number of events in which they participated. If medal success was the only criterion for coverage, U.S. women should have received 48% of NBC’s prime-time coverage. Women received approximately 46.3% of total airtime, falling nearly two points from 2004 (47.9%). Table 1 shows the percentage of airtime by sex since 1996.

caption.p: Airtime devoted to Olympic events, divided by sex. Mixed-sex events not included.
Coverage by Year for Males and Females

fn.p: Note: Total airtime devoted to males and females during NBC's prime-time coverage of the Olympic Games. Data from previous years from Tuggle, Huffman & Rosengard (2007).

sec.p: While coverage of male events was more substantial in 2008 than coverage of female events, males did not receive more coverage than females in every category. Most notably, women received far more coverage than men in individual diving, beach volleyball, and gymnastics—particularly team gymnastics. Nevertheless, males received more airtime, especially in individual events. In Table 2, men garnered more airtime than women in six of the eleven events, four of which had no female coverage. Even though in four of the six individual categories women received more coverage, men still received more airtime for individual events overall. Thus, Hypothesis 1 is supported.

fn.p: Note: aPercentages do not total 100 because mixed-gender events were not included.
bBaseball and softball received coverage in a mixed-gender feature about their elimination from the Olympic Games by the International Olympic Committee.

sec.p: Hypothesis 2 predicted that “socially acceptable” sports would comprise the bulk of women’s individual and team coverage. As Table 3 shows, nearly 60% of women’s coverage was devoted to gymnastics and swimming or diving. The authors argue that beach volleyball should be included in this list of socially acceptable sports, as since its arrival as an official Olympic sport in 1996, it has been widely cited by media and academia as an example of popularity driven by sex appeal (e.g., Armstrong, 2000; Bissell & Duke, 2007; Lines, 2000, 2007). With the inclusion of this sport in the socially acceptable category, nearly 75% of the coverage of women’s sports was given to acceptable sports. It should be noted that it is now customary for the participants in all of these events and in track and field events to wear the equivalent of a bathing suit—making up almost 98% of the coverage. The remaining sports represented—rowing, cycling, and fencing—are not, by traditional standards, “socially acceptable” sports for women, and make up approximately 2% of coverage. Fencing coverage, receiving the smallest portion (.25%) of airtime devoted to women, consisted of an interview of the three American women who won the gold, silver, and bronze medals in the saber competition. As neither male nor female fencers received any further coverage, the three-medal sweep was probably the only reason the sport received any airtime. Hypothesis 2 was supported.

Hypothesis 3 predicted that coverage of sports involving physical bulk, power exerted against an opponent or object, or unpenalized hard contact would concentrate on men. Both male and female teams competed in all of these events except for boxing, as can be seen in Table 4. The difference based on sex was remarkable, in that it reversed the trend found in previous studies (Tuggle 1999; Tuggle et al., 2002, 2007). Overall, most power sports were not covered outside of brief news mentions and medal counts. Of the two events that did receive live or as-live coverage—track and field and cycling—women’s events received the lion’s share. The leaders in women’s coverage were the pole vault event and an awards ceremony for the discus gold medal winner, the bulk of the time (approximately 11 min) devoted to the pole vault. Consequently, Hypothesis 3 was not supported.

caption.p: Coverage of Power or Hard Contact Sports and Medals Won

fn.p: Note: Medals data from Sports Reference (2008).

caption.p: Coverage of and Participation by Women 1996–2008

fn.p: Note: Participation data from Sports Reference (2008).

caption.p: Coverage of Women’s Basketball, Soccer, and Softball

fn.p: Note: Data from previous years from Tuggle, Huffman & Rosengard (2007).

sec.p: Hypothesis 4 predicted that on-camera comments would be more likely to come from male participants or observers. It was supported, as male sources received significantly more airtime than female sources. The only category in which the opposite was true was the smallest (family and friends) because of a long interview with the mother of swimming star Michael Phelps. While it is not known what percentage of current and former coaches present at the Olympics were male, the vast majority of comments came from current athletes, and 60% of those were men, overrepresenting the 53% majority of male athletes.

sec.title: Conclusions and Discussion
sec.p: In 2008, female representation grew to 48% of the U.S. team, and yet coverage of women’s events fell to 46.3%. This is in contrast to previous years, when coverage exceeded participation for women. In Athens in 2004, for example, women made up 40.7% of the U.S. team, yet received 47.9% of airtime. For those events that did receive airtime, the Beijing Olympics upheld the long-observed maxim that for female athletes to garner media coverage, they must be involved in socially acceptable individual sports and/or sports that highlight body type. Women who take part in sports that involve either power or hard body contact are particularly unlikely to receive media coverage. When women engage in stereotypically feminine events, or look pretty or graceful, they will receive coverage, but risk being shunned if they venture from that space.

As in 1996, 2000, and 2004, gymnastics accounted for the largest percentage of airtime devoted to women. More recently, beach volleyball has come to prominence, beginning in 2004. While there is no doubt of the athletic prowess of the gold medal-winning American women’s team, it is curious that while men’s volleyball coverage was split nearly equally between beach and court volleyball, women’s court volleyball received no coverage, despite the fact that those athletes won a silver medal. In contrast, women’s beach volleyball was the second-most covered event for women at the Olympics.

Since 1996, women’s representation in the “big three” team sports (basketball, soccer, and softball) has precipitously declined. In 2008, they disappeared from the schedule entirely. This is despite the fact that American women remain a dominating force in the field, taking home gold medals in basketball and soccer, and a silver medal in softball (Sports Reference, 2008). Meanwhile, men’s basketball and baseball each received more than 20 min of airtime.

Softball and baseball were the focus of a feature on August 18, 2008, lasting 4 min and 40 s. The topic of the feature was the elimination of both sports from Olympic competition, apparently for opposite reasons. (Men’s) baseball teams fail to attract the star-caliber players that are common in soccer and basketball, which make the competitions less than thrilling. On the other hand, the U.S. softball team is such a dominating force that there is virtually no competition for the gold medal. This might also explain why NBC chose to provide only limited coverage of these two sports, and yet the men’s team received 24 min of event coverage, while the women’s team received none.

Men not only get more coverage, they are given more opportunity to speak about their accomplishments. The number of female athletes quoted falls at about 40% of the total number of interviews, lower than the overall coverage percentage. Although NBC used only a small number of quotes from male coaches, the network used no live or taped comments from female coaches. This was also true of the 2004 Olympics in Athens. NBC’s coverage of the 2008 Olympics and the three before it was, of course, an improvement compared to the time when women’s participation in almost any sport was socially unacceptable. But perhaps more noteworthy than the amount of coverage is what is covered. Even today, it seems that women are accepted as athletes only if they continue to look and act as women are expected to look and act.

It is important to remember that a network’s primary concern is to deliver audiences to advertisers, and consequently it is likely to maximize audience sizes by putting the most popular sports events during prime time. It is not the contention of the authors that NBC is intentionally marginalizing any athletes. Instead, the network appears to be responding to the general public’s interest level in various sports, which was, in turn, influenced by social attitudes about femininity. Indeed, five of the top eight events in terms of ratings were women’s swimming and gymnastics (Magna International, Inc., 2008). Nevertheless, by following public opinion, there is a missed opportunity to change public opinion. Boutlier and San Giovanni (1983) noted that the media’s treatment of the relationship between women and sport shapes the direction and content of that relationship. A decision to spend more airtime on socially “unacceptable” sports may go a long way to making it “acceptable.” Based on the network’s ratings and profit success from the Beijing Games, however, there seems to be little incentive for NBC to change its approach when covering the 2012 Olympics in London.

fn.label: Declaration of Conflicting Interests
fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The authors received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
Broadcast segment is defined as coverage of a particular sport from a particular venue. The segment is considered to have ended when the venue, sport, or event changes.
